Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: a person involved in the conversations

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: But shortly after those discussions, Mr. Sutskever did the unexpected: He sided with board members to oust Mr. Altman
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: two people familiar with the board’s deliberations

Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: three people who were on the call

Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: two people familiar with the exchange

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Nearly all of OpenAI’s 800 employees had threatened to follow Mr. Altman to Microsoft, which asked him to lead an A.I. lab with Greg Brockman, who quit his roles as OpenAI’s president and board chairman in solidarity with Mr. Altman.

Document Sources.Source Justification: an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: They said that the subsidiary would be controlled by the nonprofit board and that each director’s fiduciary duty would be to “humanity, not OpenAI investors,” the company said on its website.
Document Sources.Source Justification: the company said on its website

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Sam Altman called an OpenAI board member’s research paper a danger to the company weeks before he was ousted as its chief executive.
Another member, Ilya Sutskever, thought Mr. Altman was not always being honest when talking with the board.
The news that he was being pushed out came in a videoconference on Friday afternoon, when Mr. Sutskever, who had worked closely with Mr. Altman at OpenAI for eight years, read him a statement.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who had worked closely with Mr. Altman at OpenAI for eight years

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The decision stunned OpenAI’s employees and exposed board members to tough questions about their qualifications to manage such a high-profile company.
The statement he read to Mr. Altman said that Mr. Altman was being fired because he wasn’t “consistently candid in his communications with the board.”
Helen Toner, an OpenAI board member, defended the research paper she co-wrote.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: board member; director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Mr. Altman complained that the research paper seemed to criticize OpenAI’s efforts to keep its A.I. technologies safe while praising the approach taken by Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival, according to an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times.

In the email, Mr. Altman said that he had reprimanded Ms. Toner for the paper and that it was dangerous to the company, particularly at a time, he added, when the Federal Trade Commission was investigating OpenAI over the data used to build its technology.
Ms. Toner defended it as an academic paper that analyzed the challenges that the public faces when trying to understand the intentions of the countries and companies developing A.I.
“I did not feel we’re on the same page on the damage of all this,” he wrote in the email. “Any amount of criticism from a board member carries a lot of weight.”
“After a series of reasonably amicable negotiations, the co-founders of Anthropic were able to negotiate their exit on mutually agreeable terms,”
In a second statement, Anthropic added that there was “no attempt to ‘oust’ Sam Altman at the time the founders of Anthropic left OpenAI.”

During the call, Jason Kwon, OpenAI’s chief strategy officer, said the board was endangering the future of the company by pushing out Mr. Altman. This, he said, violated the members’ responsibilities.

Ms. Toner disagreed. The board’s mission was to ensure that the company creates artificial intelligence that “benefits all of humanity,” and if the company was destroyed, she said, that could be consistent with its mission. In the board’s view, OpenAI would be stronger without Mr. Altman.
At 5:15 a.m. on Monday, he posted on X, formerly Twitter, that “I deeply regret my participation in the board’s actions.”
